'Trifluoroacetic acid' ('TFA') is the simplest stable The even simpler
'fluoroformic acid' is not isolable in substance; in protic media it
disintegrates rapidly through a proton-catalyzed pathway into hydrogen fluoride
and carbon dioxide. See  perfluorinated carboxylic acid chemical compound,
with the formula CF 3CO 2H. It is a strong carboxylic acid
due to the influence of the electronegative trifluoromethyl group. TFA is almost
100,000-fold more acidic than acetic acid. TFA is widely used in organic
chemistry.
